text: Wow I knew this theme sounded familiar. The composer Takayuki Hattori also composed for Mobile Suit Gundam: The Origin, amongst numerous other Japanese tv and movie productions. He clearly has a style.

I have a little poem for this game.

A man stands on a bomb. A man stands on a brain.
The anon is squished in demo.. and promptly goes insane.
The music is Perrr Fect., but I'm never gonna play this game.

author: LightyGab

text:
Played the demo as a kid, loved it enough to buy Kurushi (as its known in Europe) and later its sequel. Definitely worth it for me, I played this endlessly, so addicting and the beautiful (sometimes stressful) music fits perfectly.
Proof that demo discs worked and people bought games that you otherwise wouldn't even know about.

text: eat your heart out dragon quest, something got more epic :)

author: NetConsole

text: Intelligent Qube aka. Kurushi has a very imposing (and somewhat pretentious) aesthetic. Also the core gameplay is so simple they needed something to fill up the rest of the PlayStation CD!

text: An often forgotten gem on the PS1, I remember playing the demo repeatedly as a kid, and then finally downloading it from the PSN store when I was older.

text: Never thought this random game on ps1 classic would actually get me kinda hooked.
author: Autumn's Orchard

text: I still can't believe that this weird but addictive PS1 puzzle game has such a quality soundtrack. This is AAA quality right there, some parts I could imagine playing during an enchanting movie scene. Over the years, Healing Light (#821) has become one of my favorite peaceful VGM ever.
author: SupraDarky

text: Man, this is so Indiana Jones - my favorite movie ever!
author: Zymphn

text: This game is so bizarre and surreal! Definitely one of the oddities in the PS1 catalog, which is filled to the brim with them. And I could totally imagine this song playing during an RPG travel montage cutscene.
